column1: #Text=Optimization guide for Power BI - Power BI | Microsoft Docs
#Text=This article provides guidance that enables developers and administrators to produce and maintain optimized Power BI solutions.
#Text=You can optimize your solution at different architectural layers.
#Text=Visualizations, including dashboards, Power BI reports, and Power BI paginated reports
#Text=The environment, including capacities, data gateways, and the network
#Text=The data model supports the entire visualization experience.
#Text=Data models are either external-hosted or internal-hosted, and in Power BI they are referred to as datasets.
#Text=It's important to understand your options, and to choose the appropriate dataset type for your solution.
#Text=There are three dataset modes: Import, DirectQuery, and Composite.
#Text=For more information, see Datasets in the Power BI service, and
#Text=Dataset modes in the Power BI service.
#Text=DirectQuery model guidance in Power BI Desktop
#Text=Composite model guidance in Power BI Desktop
#Text=Power BI visualizations can be dashboards, Power BI reports, or Power BI paginated reports.
#Text=Each has different architectures, and so each has their own guidance.
#Text=It's important to understand that Power BI maintains a cache for your dashboard tiles—except live report tiles, and streaming tiles.
#Text=For more information, see Data refresh in Power BI (Tile refresh).
#Text=If your dataset enforces dynamic row-level security (RLS), be sure to understand performance implications as tiles will cache on a per-user basis.
#Text=When you pin live report tiles to a dashboard, they're not served from the query cache.
#Text=Instead, they behave like reports, and make queries to back-end cores on the fly.
#Text=As the name suggests, retrieving the data from the cache provides better and more consistent performance than relying on the data source.
#Text=One way to take advantage of this functionality is to have dashboards be the first landing page for your users.
#Text=Pin often-used and highly requested visuals to the dashboards.
#Text=In this way, dashboards become a valuable "first line of defense", which delivers consistent performance with less load on the capacity.
#Text=Users can still click through to a report to analyze details.
#Text=For DirectQuery and live connection datasets, the cache is updated on a periodic basis by querying the data source.
#Text=By default, it happens every hour, though you can configure a different frequency in the dataset settings.
#Text=Each cache update will send queries to the underlying data source to update the cache.
#Text=The number of queries that generate depends on the number of visuals pinned to dashboards that rely on the data source.
#Text=Notice that if row-level security is enabled, queries are generated for each different security context.
#Text=For example, consider there are two different roles that categorize your users, and they have two different views of the data.
#Text=During query cache refresh, Power BI generates two sets of queries.
#Text=There are several recommendations for optimizing Power BI report designs.
#Text=When reports are based on a DirectQuery dataset, for additional report design optimizations, see DirectQuery model guidance in Power BI Desktop (Optimize report designs).
#Text=The more data that a visual needs to display, the slower that visual is to load.
#Text=While this principle seems obvious, it's easy to forget.
#Text=For example: suppose you have a large dataset.
#Text=Atop of that dataset, you build a report with a table.
#Text=End users use slicers on the page to get to the rows they want—typically, they're only interested in a few dozen rows.
#Text=A common mistake is to leave the default view of the table unfiltered—that is, all 100M+ rows.
#Text=The data for these rows loads into memory and is uncompressed at every refresh.
#Text=This processing creates huge demands for memory.
#Text=The solution: use the "Top N" filter to reduce the max number of items that the table displays.
#Text=You can set the max item to larger than what users would need, for example, 10,000.
#Text=The result is the end-user experience doesn't change, but memory use drops greatly.
#Text=A similar design approach to the above is suggested for every visual in your report.
#Text=Ask yourself, is all the data in this visual needed?
#Text=Are there ways to filter the amount of data shown in the visual with minimal impact to the end-user experience?
#Text=Remember, tables in particular can be expensive.
#Text=The above principle applies equally to the number of visuals added to a report page.
#Text=It's highly recommended you limit the number of visuals on a particular report page to only what is necessary.
#Text=Drillthrough pages and report page tooltips are great ways to provide additional details without jamming more visuals onto the page.
#Text=Be sure to put each custom visual through its paces to ensure high performance.
#Text=Poorly optimized Power BI visuals can negatively affect the performance of the entire report.
#Text=Power BI paginated report designs can be optimized by applying best practice design to the report's data retrieval.
#Text=For more information, see Data retrieval guidance for paginated reports.
#Text=Also, ensure your capacity has sufficient memory allocated to the paginated reports workload.
#Text=You can optimize the Power BI environment by configuring capacity settings, sizing data gateways, and reducing network latency.
#Text=When using capacities—available with Power BI Premium (P SKUs), Premum Per User (PPU) licenses, or
#Text=Power BI Embedded (A SKUs, A4-A6)—you can manage capacity settings.
#Text=For more information, see Managing Premium capacities.
#Text=For guidance on how to optimize your capacity, see Optimizing Premium capacities.
#Text=A gateway is required whenever Power BI must access data that isn't accessible directly over the Internet.
#Text=You can install the on-premises data gateway on a server on-premises, or VM-hosted Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS).
#Text=To understand gateway workloads and sizing recommendations, see On-premises data gateway sizing.
#Text=Network latency can impact report performance by increasing the time required for requests to reach the Power BI service, and for responses to be delivered.
#Text=Tenants in Power BI are assigned to a specific region.
#Text=To determine where your tenant is located, see Where is my Power BI tenant located?
#Text=When users from a tenant access the Power BI service, their requests always route to this region.
#Text=As requests reach the Power BI service, the service may then send additional requests—for example, to the underlying data source, or a data gateway—which are also subject to network latency.
#Text=Tools such as Azure Speed Test provide an indication of network latency between the client and the Azure region.
#Text=In general, to minimize the impact of network latency, strive to keep data sources, gateways, and your Power BI cluster as close as possible.
#Text=Preferably, they reside within the same region.
#Text=If network latency is an issue, try locating gateways and data sources closer to your Power BI cluster by placing them inside cloud-hosted virtual machines.
#Text=You can monitor performance to identify bottlenecks.
#Text=Slow queries—or report visuals—should be a focal point of continued optimization.
#Text=Monitoring can be done at design time in Power BI Desktop, or on production workloads in Power BI Premium capacities.
#Text=For more information, see Monitoring report performance in Power BI.
#Text=For more information about this article, check out the following resources:
#Text=Whitepaper: Planning a Power BI Enterprise Deployment
